qas.question: What kind of phonemes are soft sounds?

answers.text: consonant phonemes with palatal secondary articulation

qas.question: What kind of accent can mark stress?
What kind of words can acute accents distinguish?
What word means both lock and castle, depending on its accent?

plausible_answers.text: consonant phonemes with palatal secondary articulation

qas.question: What kind of phenomes are uncommon words?

plausible_answers.text: between pairs of almost all consonants

qas.question: Where are uncommon words usually found?
What feature of the language is an uncommon word considered?
What are uncommon words or names considered to be and not usually indicated?
What is an uncommon word used to mark?

context: Russian distinguishes between <a0_0><b4_0>consonant phonemes with palatal secondary articulation<b4_0/><a0_0/> and those without, the so-called soft and hard sounds. This distinction is found <b5_0>between pairs of almost all consonants<b5_0/> and is one of the most <b6_0>distinguishing<b6_0/> features of the language. Another important aspect is the reduction of unstressed vowels. Stress, which is <b7_0>unpredictable<b7_0/>, is not normally indicated orthographically though an <a1_0>optional acute accent<a1_0/> (знак ударения, znak udareniya) may be used to mark <b8_0>stress<b8_0/>, such as to distinguish between <a2_0>homographic words<a2_0/>, for example замо́к (<a3_0>zamok<a3_0/>, meaning a lock) and за́мок (zamok, meaning a castle), or to indicate the proper pronunciation of uncommon words or names.
